conversation.content: Hello doctor, I have abdominal pain and bloating, and I keep vomiting repeatedly.
May I ask when this situation started?
The symptoms started after I got drunk on the night of the first day of the Lunar New Year.
Approximately how much alcohol did you drink?
I drank every day during the Spring Festival. I’m not sure about the exact amount, but I often drank until I was drunk.
Could you please provide the results of your complete blood count (CBC)?

The blood test results showed: TBIL 123.1 μmol/L, DBIL 99.0 μmol/L, ALT 609 U/L, AST 308 U/L, ALK-P 245 U/L, GGT 1057 U/L, BUN 4.63 mmol/L, Creatinine 57.9 μmol/L, Glucose 13.86 mmol/L, Cholesterol 4.3 mmol/L, Triglyceride 6.25 mmol/L, WBC 16.49 ×10⁹/L, Neut% 89.1%, RBC 5.10 ×10¹²/L, Hb 159 g/L, Platelet 232.0 ×10⁹/L.
On physical examination, was there any evidence of ascites?
Shifting dullness was negative, and there was no ascites.
What were the findings regarding bowel sounds and percussion on abdominal examination?
Bowel sounds were decreased, about 1 time per minute; percussion revealed a tympanic note.
Have you undergone any imaging examinations?
Yes, I had an ultrasound, gastroscopy, serum amylase, urine amylase, and an abdominal CT scan.
What were the results of the ultrasound (USG), gastroscopy, serum amylase, urine amylase, and abdominal CT?
Are your current vital signs stable?
Body temperature 38.5°C, pulse 120 beats/min, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 149/110 mmHg. Vital signs are basically stable.
Is there evidence of stones in the common bile duct?
Ultrasound showed dilation of the common bile duct, but did not clearly indicate common bile duct stones.
Do you currently have abdominal tenderness, rebound tenderness, or signs of peritoneal irritation?
Abdominal examination showed tenderness in the upper abdomen, without rebound tenderness or signs of peritoneal irritation.

Diagnosis:
1. Conclusion: common bile duct stones complicated by obstructive jaundice, severe pancreatitis
   Reasoning: fever, abdominal pain and distension, with elevated amylase (AMY) and jaundice; presence of gallstones and dilation of the common bile duct support the diagnosis of pancreatitis. CT indicates severe disease.

2. Conclusion: severe pancreatitis complicated by paralytic ileus
   Reasoning: short-term heavy alcohol intake and binge eating, abdominal distension, tympanic percussion note, absence of ascites but significant gas retention in the gastrointestinal tract.
Treatment: 1. ICU admission is required for critical care management. While closely monitoring renal function, aggressive fluid resuscitation should be performed. If respiratory status worsens, nasal high-flow oxygen therapy (NHF) or endotracheal intubation is required. Blood cultures should be obtained, and antibiotics administered based on culture results. Continuous infusion of anti-pancreatic enzyme agents should be given. A repeat abdominal CT should be performed after 48 hours to assess for abscess formation or necrotic cavities. After abdominal pain improves, early initiation of oral nutritional support is recommended.
